topic.title: DI_RCP

note.p: The figure below is sourced from the DI_RCP layer of http://bby1dms01/DocMgmt/getfile.cfm?file_id=428047&file_version_id=685809

body.p: The DI_RCP provides the ability to implement fast protection switching using an external device which processes the outgoing Ethernet packets (e.g. a control CPU or an FPGA). Note that the DIGI-G5 DI_RCP is not compatible with external processors designed for DIGI120 or DIGI-G4 due to differences in the PDU formats.

The DI_RCP reports defects/alarms aggregated from across the device every 125µs and various PMON every 5ms. The 5ms interval is generated off of the 125µs interval and they are edge aligned. The latched defect state is sent and cleared every 125µs (i.e. a transient defect will be recorded and only cleared after transmission). A full list of defects/alarms/PMON, and their sources, is provided in Section Defect/Alarm/PMON Sources.

All of the defects/alarms/PMONs are mapped into 35 different Ethernet PDU’s based off of Channel ID and or Pool ID of the source. The PDU TYPE is indicated using the Ethertype field for TYPE=1-56. Note that some PDU’s have identical formats and use the TYPE number to indicate a different source. Any unused Channels or Pool IDs within the PDU’s contain undefined values. The PDU’s are fully defined in in the subsections of Section PDU Formats.

The DI_RCP has a standard 802.3 half duplex 1GE port (TX only) and uses a maximum bandwidth of 0.58 Gbps. Information reported to the DI_RCP is undefined for any channel that is not provisioned. The GE port supports full duplex but the RX port is not needed and all incoming RX traffic is discarded. The RX SerDes lane can be left disconnected and the G5 SDK will provision the port appropriately to ensure local faults on the receive port do not result in PDUs being sent on the TX port. The packet interval is based off of the 125µs and 5ms intervals and the DI_RCP uses the generic Ethernet Frame outlined in Section Generic Ethernet Frame.

p.i: Packet scheduling is implemented using a simple round-robin scheme between all of the PDU types with an enable/disable is provided on a per PDU basis. If disabled, the PDU will be excluded from the round-robin and no packet will be sent for that PDU. Defect states are latched and cleared upon transmission
